variant.question: Any prolonged exposure to noise in excess of 90 dB can end up in:

A pilot visits their AME for a medical revalidation. During a hearing test, he/she was diagnosed with deafness of high frequency. He/she then admitted that for the last few years he/she was doing walkarounds without ear plugs. Which kind of hearing loss is most likely to have occured?
Noise induced hearing loss is influenced by the

options.text: duration and intensity of a noise.
suddenness of onset of a noise.
duration of a noise but not its intensity.
intensity of the noise but not its duration.

variant.question: What is the main cause of conductive deafness?

options.text: A blockage of the outer or middle ear, e.g. ear wax, or fluid in the middle ear.
A combination of lifestyle, e.g. smoking, and environmental factors, e.g. stress.
An infectious disease of the inner ear that affects, for example, balance and hearing.
Prolonged exposure to high-frequency sounds, such as turbine-engine noise.

options.text: is a condition resulting in permanent hearing loss of selected frequencies.
is also known as presbycusis and is associated with pressure damage to the middle ear.
is a temporary hearing loss, the nerve cells frequently recover.

Any prolonged exposure to noise in excess of 85 d
B can result in
Presbycusis..

options.text: results in a reduction in the perception of high tones first.
results in a reduction in the perception of all tones equally.
will not affect a pilot's hearing if he/she is wearing ear-plugs all the time.
leads to a reduction in the perception of low tones first.

variant.question: What are the main causes of Noise Induced Hearing Loss (NIHL)?

options.text: Acoustic trauma and prolonged exposure to noise levels above 85 dB.
Head injury and frequent exposure to high pitch sounds above 20 kHz.
Genetic predisposition and the natural ageing process.
Continuous exposure to high frequency sound and impulse noise.

variant.question: The group of bones called the hammer, anvil, and stirrup are situated in the

A young pilot visits his aeromedical examiner for the routine renewal of his medical certificate. During the examination, the AME discovers that the pilot has difficulties hearing certain frequencies, especially in the range of speech, while other frequencies remain unaffected. Upon interrogation of the AME, the pilot admits that he has regularly been doing his outside inspections without wearing ear plugs. Which kind of hearing loss has occurred?
Select from the options below the correct statement concerning the human ear.

options.text: The chain of ossicles is in the middle ear and connects the tympanic membrane to the oval window.
At the oval window, the pressure waves are transformed into nerve pulses.
The Eustachian tube connects the inner ear to the pharynx.
The frequency of a sound determines which hair cells will respond to it; the higher the pitch, the further down the cochlea will it be processed.

variant.question: Select from the options below the correct statement concerning the human ear.

options.text: At the oval window, vibrating the chain of ossicles induces pressure waves in the endolymph.
The chain of ossicles is in the middle ear and connects the tympanic membrane to the semi-circular canals.
Presbyacusis (hearing loss with age) is due to wear of the chain of ossicles.
When standing upright, the utriculus senses linear acceleration along the z axis and gravity.

variant.question: Select the correct statement concerning the human ear from the options below.

options.text: At the oval window, vibrating the chain of ossicles induces pressure waves in the endolymph.
When standing upright, the utriculus senses linear acceleration along the z axis as well as gravity.
Presbycusis (hearing loss with age) is due to gradual wear of the chain of ossicles.
The chain of ossicles is in the middle ear and connects the vibrations in the tympanic membrane to the sensors in the semicircular canals.

variant.question: Noise induced hearing loss (NIHL) is caused by..

options.text: damage to the sensitive hair cells in the cochlea due to overexposure to noise.
pressure differences on both sides of the eardrum.

variant.question: Noise induced hearing loss (NIHL) is caused by..

options.text: damage to the sensitive hair cells in the cochlea due to over-exposure to noise.
pressure differences on both sides of the eardrum.

variant.question: Conductive hearing loss can be caused by: 1. damage to the ossicles in the middle ear caused by infection or trauma, 2. a damage of the auditory nerve, 3. an obstruction in the outer ear, 4. a ruptured tympanic membrane.

options.text: 1 and 3 are correct, 2 and 4 are false

variant.question: Which of the following terms describe some of the different parts of the auditory system?

options.text: Auditory canal, eardrum, ossicles, cochlea, and auditory nerve.
Ear canal, eardrum, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and Eustachian nerve.
External ear, eardrum, malleus, incus, stapes, and vestibular nerve.
Ear canal, Eustachian membrane, cochlea, and tympanic nerve.

1. intensity of the noise,2. attitude of the person towards the noise,3. exposure time to the noise,4. frequency of the noise.
Resonance of the body parts can result from

options.text: acceleration along the longitudinal body axis.

variant.question: Which part of the ear could be affected due to air pressure changes during climb and/or descent?

options.text: The Eustachian tube and the tympanic membrane (ear drum).

variant.question: Which is an adequate measure to reduce the risk of noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL)?

options.text: Use a noise-cancelling headset and/or ear plugs
Regularly train the inner ear by exposition to sudden, high-intensity sound
Gradually adapt to rising sound pressure levels
Keep a balanced diet rich in vitamin A

variant.question: A TCAS Resolution Advisory (RA) sounds in flight. Which part of the inner ear carries the sound of the alert to the crew?

options.text: The air-filled parts of the cochlea.

options.text: the sensitive membrane in the cochlea.

A TCAS Resolution Advisory (RA) sounds on the flight deck. Which part of the inner ear is responsible for the perception of the sound alert?

options.text: The fluid-filled portion of the cochlea.
The air-filled portion of the cochlea.

variant.question: What can pilots do to reduce the probability of suffering from noise-induced hearing loss?

options.text: Use hearing protection equipment, like earplugs, or active noise-reduction headsets.
Limit the duration of exposure to high-frequency noise (above 20 kHz) to less than 5 hours.
Avoid any kind of artificial blockage of the ear canal, including unusual earwax build-up.
Use the Valsalva manoeuvre when experiencing a ringing or buzzing of the ears due to noise.

variant.question: What can pilots do to reduce the possibility of suffering from noise-induced hearing loss?

options.text: Use hearing protection equipment, like earplugs, or active noise-reduction headsets.
Use the Valsalva manoeuvre when experiencing a ringing or buzzing of the ears due to noise.
Limit the duration of exposure to high-frequency noise (above 20 KHz) to less than 5 hours.
Avoid any kind of artificial blockage of the ear canal, including unusual earwax build-up.

options.text: a one-time exposure to impulse noise above 120 dB and/or continuous exposure to noise above 85 dB.
the use of so-called “active headsets” which produce an additional noise of their own.
exposure to noise of any intensity, when the hair cells do not have the opportunity to recreate.

caused by hearing deterioration as part of the process of ageing.
caused by damage to the eardrum or ossicles by noise above 90 dB.
governed by the intensity of noise above the 103 dB level.

variant.question: Which of the following can result in noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL)?

options.text: An acoustic trauma or prolonged exposure to noise in excess of 85 dB.
Genetic predisposition and the process of ageing.
Prolonged exposure to high frequency noise and impulse noise.
A head injury and frequent exposure to high frequencies above 20 kHz.
